1 MARCH.part3: VERSE 30 venting their vitriol against those they dislike.
1 MARCH.part4: Backbiters, haters of God, despiteful, proud, boasters, inventors of evil things, disobedient to parents,
1 MARCH.part5:
Paul lists several characteristics of people who hate the Lord Jesus Christ. They are despiteful. They treat those they dislike with injurious insolence. They are loud, boisterous, abusing the characters and persons of those whom they can. We see such people often in social media. All day long they rant against their political opponents and those in positions of authority. Quite often we see them in the news, protesting in the streets and venting their vitriol against those they dislike.

Paul also says they are proud and boasters. Again, we see them everywhere in society today. They exalt themselves continually while disparaging others. Today's management gurus extol pride and self-esteem as values to be cherished if one wants to get ahead in life. Parents and educators are taught they should never criticize or punish children but instead encourage them to love themselves and develop self-confidence and pride. Paul in his second epistle to Timothy warned that such a trend will become prominent during the perilous times just before the second coming of the Lord.

The Bible has much to say about the sin of pride. Followers of the Lord Jesus Christ must guard against this deadly sin. We are to learn of Him who was meek and lowly in heart [Matthew 11:29], who washed the disciples' feet, humbled Himself and bore our sins on the Cross. Never forget, "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast." [Ephesians 2:8-9]
1 MARCH.part7: Yea, all of you be subject one to another, and be clothed with humility: for God resisteth the proud, and giveth grace to the humble. - 1 Peter 5:5b

2 MARCH.part3: VERSE 30 obviously merciless people who do not care about
2 MARCH.part4: Backbiters, haters of God, despiteful, proud, boasters, inventors of evil things, disobedient to parents,
2 MARCH.part5:
Paul says these God-haters with reprobate minds invent evil things. He does not specify what the "evil things" are. They could mean new ways of doing evil, or new ideas of sinning. Whichever interpretation, both are prevalent and multiplying in our modern society. Phone scams, internet scams, child pornography, drug trafficking and terrorism are just a few of the countless new types of evil we see daily in the news; crimes that were unheard of just a few generations ago. The perpetrators are obviously merciless people who do not care about the pain and suffering they inflict on their victims.

And then there are those who are not content with the ordinary and "traditional" ways of sinning. They seek the thrill of new ideas of sinfulness, sinking to new depths of depravity. Tragically, many of these evils are targeted at our children. For example, under the guise of "inclusion" and "love", children are taught to embrace all types of perverted sexual identities, from homosexuality to bisexuality to asexuality. Admonition of children in any form is also wrong. As a result, we have a generation of young people who disobey parents and despise authority. Satan is clearly out to destroy the family unit.

As Christians, our only defence is to lead godly lives, and bring up our children in the nurture and admonition of the Lord. We should also be united as a church family, loving and caring for one another, assembling together regularly for fellowship, Bible study and worship, and praying together for our church and families.
2 MARCH.part7: For we wrestle not against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this world, against spiritual wickedness in high places. - Ephesians 6:12

3 MARCH.part4: Without understanding, covenantbreakers, without natural affection, implacable, unmerciful.
3 MARCH.part5:
Paul concludes his description of evil-doers with five more characteristics in verse 31 - one of which we have considered earlier. "Without understanding" describes the man who is a fool, who will not use the mind and brain that God has given to him. Consequently, he is unable to discern between what is right or wrong in the eyes of his Creator. Covenant breakers are disloyal and break agreements, oaths and vows, thus cannot be trusted. In the light of the other sins Paul listed, this term may have a special emphasis pertaining to the marriage bond. Divorce rates in modern societies are soaring and a common reason cited by couples for divorce is "irreconcilable differences" or "irretrievable breakdown of marriage". Paul labels this unforgiving, vindictive attitude as "implacable".

"Without natural affections" refers to an absence of the affection founded upon natural God-ordained relationships such as that between parent and child, or husband and wife. This evil prevailed in Paul's days and before, among the pagans who sacrificed their own children to idols. Today it takes the cruel form of abortion where millions of unborn babies are killed every year throughout the world. In the United Kingdom for example, repeat abortions among teenage girls has been rising.

Sadly, many of these sins are found even among professing Christians. This is something the Apostle warned would happen especially in the last days. May the Lord have mercy on us. May His Holy Spirit speak to our hearts to turn away from such evil and come to Him in humble repentance and obedience.
3 MARCH.part7: For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ. - Philippians 3:20

4 MARCH.part4: Who knowing the judgment of God, that they which commit such things are worthy of death, not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do them.
4 MARCH.part5:
In January 1996, the Church of England's Doctrine Commission published a report entitled "The Mystery of Salvation", which basically said that, while Hell exists, the traditional images of Hell as an eternal torment were wrong. Bishop John Taylor, one of the report's authors said, "Hell as ultimate non-being is the way in which we have put it. The horrible demons are the imaginations of inventors and medievalists." The report had more good news for unbelievers - while salvation comes only from God, and only through the cross, it did not mean that God rejects people of other faiths. "God will save ultimately those who are willing to be saved, by their penitence and acceptance of the love which stretches out to them."

Any true follower of the Lord Jesus Christ who knows and takes the Bible seriously should recognise that the above statements are heresies. They contradict everything the Lord taught about hell and judgment. The Lord Jesus often warned His listeners that hell is a real place of torment and eternal punishment. He warned that "there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth". By this He meant that in hell, people would not only suffer in agony, but they would also feel much regret.

Tragically, many churches continue to preach such a perverted Gospel. Little wonder that the world is plunging headlong towards the sad state foretold by the Apostle in this chapter. It is vitally important for those who profess to be followers of the Lord Jesus Christ to search the Scriptures and confirm for ourselves what the Bible teaches about sin and judgment.
4 MARCH.part7: And I saw the dead, small and great, stand before God; ... and the dead were judged out of those things which were written in the books, according to their works. - Revelation 20:12

5 MARCH.part4: Who knowing the judgment of God, that they which commit such things are worthy of death, not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do them.
5 MARCH.part5: We mock hell when we commit deeds worthy of death whilst knowing the judgment of God is coming. Judgment may feel very far away to us when we are in the dark, when we think we are alone, experiencing the fleeting pleasure of sin. And even though God has announced that those who sin deserve death, we continue sinning anyway, and His warnings of judgment fall on deaf ears. The pleasure of sin blinds us, and we presume that God will simply turn a blind eye to our indulgence of the flesh. Some long-time churchgoers or professing Christians may be tempted to think that Paul's warning in verse 32 is for the unbeliever who is very distant from God, not them. But Paul later points out in Romans 2:12 he is referring to all, even the believer who is consciously trying to abide by God's laws. The same root of sin rules in our hearts, expressing itself in some way in our lives. It is true we may not receive immediate judgment for our sin in this life. But Paul tells us "be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap" [Galatians 6:7]. Do not buy into the lie that judgment for sin will not come. We will eventually reap the everlasting consequences of sins we commit now. "Ye that love the Lord, hate evil" [Psalm 97:10].
5 MARCH.part7: Dear Father, thank You that Your judgment is just, and thank You for Your mercy available to all. Save us from our blindness to the consequence of sin and help us to repent and to hate sin. In Jesus' name, Amen.

6 MARCH.part4: Who knowing the judgment of God, that they which commit such things are worthy of death, not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do them.
6 MARCH.part5:
Even the Bible declares that there can be pleasure in sin. The deception of its pleasure is that it is only temporary, "for a season" [Hebrews 11:25]. The prodigal son in Luke 15 was tempted by all the pleasures of the world beyond his home. He asked for his inheritance from his father, left home and foolishly squandered it on the world's temporal pleasures. The Bible says, "there [he] wasted his substance with riotous living." After the prodigal son had spent all and a famine arose, he was forced to feed pigs to survive.

If sin were as distasteful as its consequence, we would easily flee from it. But sin is seductive and irresistible. Sin wraps itself in what looks harmless and pleasurable. The fruit on the tree of knowledge of good and evil was "good for food", "pleasant to the eyes" and "a tree to be desired to make one wise" [Genesis 3:6]. Sin delivers on its promise to grant temporal gratification in its first bite. But once the fleeting pleasure is over, it forces us into shame and hiding from God, and separates us from Him.

Delight no more in sin - hate it. But do not be discouraged by your sinful past - even for Paul, the battle against sin was a war against the law of his renewed mind, bringing him into captivity to the law of sin [Romans 7:23]. It is not by our own efforts, but God alone Who transforms our desires through the Lord Jesus Christ.
6 MARCH.part7: Among whom also we all had our conversation in times past in the lusts of our flesh, fulfilling the desires of the flesh and of the mind; and were by nature the children of wrath ... But God, who is rich in mercy, for His great love wherewith He loved us, Even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved;) - Ephesians 2:3-5

7 MARCH.part4: Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, whosoever thou art that judgest: for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself; for thou that judgest doest the same things.
7 MARCH.part5:
In Romans 1:18-32, Paul has shown that there is no excuse for the unbelieving Gentiles in their fallen and lost condition. God has given them sufficient knowledge of Himself through general revelation (nature). His invisible attributes of external power and divinity are clearly perceived, and consequently the wicked are without excuse [Romans 1:20]. Man knows God exists but has refused and rejected the God Who is good. The pagan Gentiles suppressed the truth by their unrighteousness, ungodliness and wickedness, and became idol worshippers, immoral and depraved. Sinful man is under God's condemnation. Upon him, God's wrath is revealed from heaven. They had no excuse for their sins and depravity before the righteous God.

"Inexcusable" is translated from the Greek word anapologetos, which means "without excuse". In Romans chapter 2, Paul begins to demonstrate that all the self-righteous are also without excuse. If the Gentiles having general revelation and the internal voice of conscience [Romans 1:18-20] were inexcusable, then much more so the Jews, the chosen people who had the Law - the revealed will of God - and thus had greater knowledge than the Gentiles. Paul shows the self-righteous are also guilty sinners and under God's wrath.

To know God, read the Bible. Find out what God has revealed about Himself [Exodus 34:6-7; Leviticus 19:2; Jeremiah 32:27]. Then find out what was said about Him and His remarkable attributes [Psalm 19:1-4; Romans 1:16-20; 1 John 4:8-10]. Finally, take a look at the amazing things He has done [Genesis 1:1; Exodus 14:10-31; John 3:16].
7 MARCH.part7: Sin can only be forgiven through the shed blood of our risen Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. - Hebrews 9:22b

8 MARCH.part4: Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, whosoever thou art that judgest: for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself; for thou that judgest doest the same things.
8 MARCH.part5:
"Whosoever thou art that judgest: for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself." Here, "thou" refers to those who pass judgment on others based on their own moral standards, and have themselves fallen short of the standard of God, the ultimate Judge. In Romans chapter 2, Paul turns his attention to the moralists. These were the people who perceived themselves to be morally superior, and had set themselves apart from heathen Gentiles. They expressed freely and critically the character and destruction of the Gentiles. They were in the habit of accusing and condemning them (the heathen Gentiles) as wicked, while excusing themselves on the grounds that they possessed the law and oracles of God, and were His chosen people. Therefore, they would escape God's judgment.

The habitual self-righteous fault-finder must remember that he himself can expect to be condemned not only by men but especially by God. The man who sins without the law, and the man who sins in the law, will both be judged. The moralist, the person who judges others, is as guilty as the person he judges. For this reason, we are not to judge, criticize and find fault with others.

In judging others, we automatically judge ourselves. Judging others elevates self and lowers others, exalts self and denigrates others. In God's eyes, this is wrong. It is sinful self-righteousness, pride and arrogance.

Instead, we are exhorted to judge ourselves. "Examine yourselves, whether ye be in the faith; prove your own selves" [2 Corinthians 13:5a]. "For if we would judge ourselves, we should not be judged" [1 Corinthians 11:31]. "If we would thoroughly search and explore ourselves and condemn and correct what we find amiss, we should prevent divine judgment" (Matthew Henry).
8 MARCH.part7: Let a man judge, not his fellow-men, but himself, lest he incur the righteous judgment of God.

9 MARCH.part4: But we are sure that the judgment of God is according to truth against them which commit such things.
9 MARCH.part5:
Paul has revealed in Romans 1:18-32 that God's wrath is revealed in judgment against the sinful Gentile because he has rejected His revelation and descended into idolatry and horrifying vice. In chapter 2, Paul indicts the Jews and all morally superior people, that based on God's truth, they are under God's judgment and without excuse also. The Jews believed they were chosen, born into the line of Abraham, and the fact they had God's law and were circumcised would exempt them from judgment. They judged others based on their own standards but did not think of themselves as sinners.

Reading the judgment described in Romans 2, we realize that nobody will escape God's judgment for personal sin. God's righteous judgment is certain and unavoidable. The judgment of the true and living God is according to truth. The expression "according to truth" has two meanings. In Hebrew, it sometimes is used to denote "truly" or "certainly". God will certainly judge and punish such deeds. (The judgment of God is according to deeds: eternal reward or punishment). Evil-doers suffer judgement and well-doers are rewarded.

Another meaning is that God will judge those who are guilty of such things (sinful acts mentioned in chapter 1) not according to appearance but based on His complete knowledge of all the evidence: "for the LORD seeth not as man seeth; for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the LORD looketh on the heart" [1 Samuel 16:7b]. However, Paul also tells us God's real desire is not judgment, but salvation that comes through repentance. Now is the time to repent and take hold of His patient love [Romans 2:4].
9 MARCH.part7: Lord, may those outside Your Kingdom be convicted of their sin [1 John 1:9] and confess the Lord Jesus as their personal Lord and Saviour [Romans 10:9-10].

10 MARCH.part4: But we are sure that the judgment of God is according to truth against them which commit such things.
10 MARCH.part5:
Man's judgment is usually subjective. Intentionally or not, our judgments are coloured by various lenses. Age, experience, conviction, personal preference, and selfishness affect the way we judge a thing. Therefore, we ought often to examine our own judgments and not be quick to condemn the actions of others. In contrast to us, God's judgments are altogether true and righteous. That is a sobering thought, for at the moment we judge and condemn another's behaviour, His true and righteous judgement falls upon us.

Often, we pride ourselves on being "better" than those whom we judge. We judge others' actions and feel better about ourselves. Perhaps, we condemn others so that we can maintain an appearance of holiness. "Not in MY house ...," "Unlike them, I would ...," "I would never ..." are some common expressions that could indicate that instead of truly being concerned for the other person, we are more concerned with portraying our own "righteousness". Take heed, for here we are warned that God is able to truly judge both others and ourselves.

How then can we avoid this tendency of being critical and censorious of others? One way would be always to regard the actions of others in the most magnanimous and charitable light while adopting the strictest view when examining ourselves. When we see others engaging in behaviour that we might not necessarily agree with, let our first response be one of love.
10 MARCH.part7: Do I point out the flaws of others because I want them to be closer to God?

11 MARCH.part4: And thinkest thou this, O man, that judgest them which do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God?
11 MARCH.part5:
Often, we engage in sinful judgment of others with a condemnatory spirit because we have a wrong thinking about sin. A common misconception we have is that there are significant differences with regard to sin. While the Bible does suggest there are varying degrees of sin, let us remember that whoever commits even one sin is pronounced guilty of all [James 2:10]. The ultimate punishment whether for one small sin, for one grievous sin, or many sins is the same - death.

We struggle to consciously think this way. Instead, in our pride we draw arbitrary distinctions with regard to sin. It would be ridiculous for an adulterer to proudly point at a murderer and say, "at least I am better than he." It is equally ridiculous for liars, online pirates, gluttons, and materialistic people to point at one another and say, "at least I am not like you." Our sins may manifest differently, but they are "the same" because they are all sins.

The problem is not that we think others are sinful. The real problem is we often do not recognise we are equally, if not more sinful than they. When our faults are pointed out to us, we tend to react defensively and say, "but my sin is different from his and therefore irrelevant to this situation." To protect ourselves, we suspend our thinking after pointing a finger at others in judgment. In short, our problem is pride. We think too highly of ourselves and too little of others.
11 MARCH.part7: How would consciousness of my own sins affect how I view others?

12 MARCH.part4: And thinkest thou this, O man, that judgest them which do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God?
12 MARCH.part5:
Another reason we are quick to point out the sin of others could be that we want to obscure and avoid thinking about our own sinful nature. We find it easy to gossip with a group of friends about the faults of others, yet we have difficulty sharing about our own struggles with sin. Perhaps, we engage in judgmentalism to avoid being judged for our own sin. In truth, what we are doing is adding sin upon sin. By condemning others in order to avoid drawing attention to ourselves, we add to ourselves the sin of not judging righteously.

The scary thing about this sin is that we seem to get away with it. We may be able to live a holy, "perfect" Christian life on earth pointing out the sins of others while managing to conceal our own. Paul here warns that even if this is the case, there is no escape from the righteous judgement of God.

You may be able to fool the world into thinking you are an exemplary Christian but what does that matter in light of the fact that God knows, and He will be the ultimate judge. Furthermore, no matter how well we hide our sins, the Bible promises that it will eventually be brought to light [1 Corinthians 4:5]. In recent years, we have seen countless examples of this even among public Christian figures, both living and dead.
12 MARCH.part7: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness. - 1 John 1:9

13 MARCH.part4: Or despisest thou the riches of His goodness and forbearance and longsuffering; not knowing that the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance?
13 MARCH.part5: Over the past few days, we have been meditating on the sin of judging others without a proper view of ourselves. Today, we are presented with a solution to this sin. Paul accused the judgmental Christians of despising the riches of God's goodness, forbearance, and longsuffering. Indeed, when we judge others and condemn them, we are implicitly saying that their sin is beyond God's patience and ability to forgive. At the same time, we are presuming on God's goodness and patience by persisting in obscuring our own sinful nature and pride, expecting He would continue to be patient with us, overlooking our own sins, even as we point out the sins of others. This is hypocrisy at its best. Towards others we cheapen the riches of God's goodness, forbearance, and longsuffering. And yet we ourselves rely on these very attributes of God's character to continue in condemning others. To deal with our hypocrisy, let us realize what the richness of God's grace and mercy means. He has promised if we truly repent of our sins and confess them, He will forgive us. When we turn to God, there is no sin which He cannot forgive. This ought to be the clear, consistent message we remind ourselves and tell others. Instead of having a "holier than thou" attitude towards others who have committed errors and transgressions, lovingly share our own experience of the riches of God's forgiveness with them. The message ought to be "just as the Lord Jesus Christ was rich enough to forgive me, He can forgive you too."
13 MARCH.part7: How many are the lost that I have lifted? How many are the chained I've helped to free? I wonder, have I done my best for Jesus, When He has done so much for me? - Ensign Edwin Young

14 MARCH.part4: Or despisest thou the riches of His goodness and forbearance and longsuffering; not knowing that the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance?
14 MARCH.part5:
This verse explicitly highlights the goodness, forbearance, and longsuffering of God. God is infinitely good. Apart from His glorious creation, God's goodness is particularly manifested in His work of redemption, where "the kindness and love of God our Saviour toward man appeared" [Titus 3:4]. The extent of God's goodness is seen in the glory of the Person and the majesty of His work given as the propitiation for our sins: the Lord Jesus Christ - the only begotten Son of God and the humiliation and sufferings He had to undergo [Philippians 2:6-8] in contrast to the unworthiness of us whom He bore the sins for. The reason for that sacrifice is so that we could be rescued from the great horrors of eternal hellfire.

We are richly blessed with both the blessings of the life that now is, and of that which is to come. God is rich, and we are directed to His wealth of goodness. This is an ocean unfathomable; we know so little of its vastness that we can only stand and gaze on its surface. The riches of divine goodness are beyond what we can ask or think. This goodness of God is manifested in His longsuffering and forbearance - how He withheld His judgment which we so rightfully deserved and gave us every opportunity to turn to Him despite our utter wilfulness and sin.

Can we then despise such riches? How then should we respond to God's goodness? Ought it not humble us and fill us with gratitude and love? It is wonderful that God acts as He does. May we not spurn such divine goodness extended towards us.
14 MARCH.part7: Father in Heaven, we thank You for such great love You have towards us. Your goodness, forbearance and longsuffering towards us is far-reaching and unsearchable. While we cannot fully comprehend it, let us immerse ourselves in it. In Jesus' Name. Amen.

15 MARCH.part4: Or despisest thou the riches of His goodness and forbearance and longsuffering; not knowing that the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance?
15 MARCH.part5:
Repentance involves the changing of one's heart and mind, and turning from one's old habits of error and sin to a new and better course of life. "The goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance" tells us it is God who deals directly with sinners as we are. Some individuals are driven to remorse and fear by the consequences of sins - Ahab was driven by Divine threats, Pharaoh by supernatural judgments, and Judas by the terror of his own conscience. But to be led to genuine repentance from sin, one must be allured by the discovery of heavenly hope, and the attraction of divine love.

Following yesterday's theme on God's goodness, it is the very nature of Divine goodness that leads sinners to true repentance. In the context of Romans 2, it makes no difference between the Jew or the Gentile. Sin is sin regardless of whether one is a descendant of Abraham or not. When we realize the exceeding sinfulness of sin and the utter goodness of God, then we will recognize our obligation to love and serve God, the great Author of our being and of the mercies we receive. The result of true repentance appeals to our gratitude, assures our hope and banishes our fears. While the goodness we secure in our repentance is so great, the consequences for us are correspondingly tremendous should we remain in wilful rebellion toward Him.

All who truly love God will feel the constraining power of His goodness. By God's goodness are we made penitent, believing, thankful, and obedient. Is this our response? May He help us.
15 MARCH.part7: When I survey the wondrous cross On which the Prince of glory died My richest gain I count but loss And pour contempt on all my pride Were the whole realm of nature mine, That were a present far too small; Love so amazing, so divine Demands my soul, my life, my all. - Isaac Watts

16 MARCH.part4: But after thy hardness and impenitent heart treasurest up unto thyself wrath against the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God.
16 MARCH.part5:
Having previously considered the goodness of God that leads us to repentance, we see another group of people who chooses the way contrary to Him and His earnest call. While some recognize the exceeding sinfulness of sin and its consequences, thereby turning to God in grief and humble repentance, others remain unyielding and obstinately in opposition to Him and His truth. Hardness of heart is not merely an insensibility of emotions or feelings. The Lord Jesus rebuked his accusers for their hardness of heart [Mark 3:5]. Paul described it as blindness [Romans 11:25]. Hard- heartedness speaks of a calloused and stubborn heart that controls a person's entire being, just as Pharaoh whose heart was hardened despite witnessing all the wonders of God and partaking in His painful judgment. He had a fixated desire to oppose God, and a zealous hatred of His truth - manifesting itself in blasphemy towards God and persecution of His people.

While it is the very effect of our human depravity, hard-heartedness does not manifest itself to its full extent overnight. Instead, it is a natural consequence of indulging in sin. The cultivation of virtue begets more virtue. Likewise, the wallowing in sin begets deeper and more grievous sin - a sinful hardening of the heart.

What then should we do, and how should we react? Dread it; withstand it; pray against it; flee from it. The Word of God exhorts us, "Harden not your heart, as in the provocation, and as in the day of temptation in the wilderness" [Psalm 95:8]. May this serve as a warning to all readers.
16 MARCH.part7: For readers who have not known the Lord, turn to Him and harden not your hearts to His call to repentance and salvation. For those who are His, pray for those who are still unrepentant and wilful in rejecting Him, that they may humbly turn to the Lord in repentance.

17 MARCH.part4: But after thy hardness and impenitent heart treasurest up unto thyself wrath against the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God.
17 MARCH.part5:
Verse 5 can be paraphrased as: "But because of your stubborn and unrepentant heart, you are storing up wrath for yourself on the day of wrath when God's righteous judgement will be revealed." There is a tinge of irony here when Paul uses the words "treasurest up". The phrase "treasurest up" or "storing up" normally refers to storing up good things (Deuteronomy 32:34; Matthew 6:20), but here Paul uses it in a negative sense. When reading this verse, the irony highlights to the reader that we ought to be storing up blessings and not wrath.

The important question is whether we are storing up judgment or blessing for ourselves. For unrepentant sinners, the Bible tells us that they will be condemned on Judgment Day when the Lord Jesus Christ returns again, or if their lives here end. But when the Lord Jesus Christ came the first time, He gave us the gift of grace by dying on the cross, so that we may escape judgment and partake of blessings in the Eternal Kingdom.

For the believer, has Christ's death on the cross become a "license to sin" instead of a motivation to flee from sin? Do we sometimes willingly indulge in sin because we will be forgiven later on anyway? Let this verse be a warning to keep us in step with God, to always keep 'short accounts' with God through frequent prayer and sincere repentance.

Let it also be an encouragement to store up blessings by drawing closer to our Saviour in His Word, by prayer and serving Him in His ministries, for our God is a God who loves to bless His people.
17 MARCH.part7: Is there more that we can do in our walk with God? Perhaps serving more or spending more time in His Word and prayer?

18 MARCH.part2: Just pay for a life of sin
18 MARCH.part4: Who will render to every man according to his deeds:
18 MARCH.part5:
In yesterday's devotion, we learnt that if we choose to remain unrepentant sinners, we will be storing up judgement. Verse 6 goes on to say that God will "render" or "payback" every man according to his deeds on earth. Paul tells us there will be "payback" for every sin committed, past, present and future on the Day of Judgement. There will be eternal judgement for sin.

To the unrepentant sinner who exclaims: "God is unfair", this verse says otherwise. God will judge everyone impartially and equitably using the same standard - works. Some of us believe the Devil's lie that we can get away with "minor sins"; that some sins are not so serious, so it is of little consequence if we commit "minor sins" every now and then.

"It's okay to tell a white lie so that my colleague's feelings are not hurt." "The restaurant forgot to charge me for a dish but that's okay. There's no need to point it out to them because it is clearly their fault." "It's okay to curse and swear to prove a point so that the other person won't make the same mistake again." These are lies we believe in. Sin is sin and there is no "grey area". Do we justify our sins in this manner?

As believers, are we taking the Lord's payment in blood for granted? Our God is gracious and yearns to forgive us. What we have to do is to repent, flee from sin and cling to our Lord and Saviour.

For those who do not know the Lord Jesus Christ yet, do you dare to face God's wrath without the covering of Christ? Accept Jesus Christ as your Lord and Saviour today!
18 MARCH.part7: Every sin committed has a price. Do we yearn to pursue a life lived for Christ knowing the price He has paid for our sins?

19 MARCH.part4: Who will render to every man according to his deeds:
19 MARCH.part5:
God will judge every man according to his deeds on earth, but this verse must be read in context of the book of Romans and also in context of the entire Bible. While it is true that God will judge us impartially according to our works, this does not mean we will be excused from eternal damnation as long as we live a life filled with good works.

In Ephesians 2:8-9, Paul tells us that it is only by grace through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ that we are saved. We are not saved by works but by grace alone. This truth is known to every Reformed believer, but it must be hammered home again because we still subconsciously believe the lie that good works save.

Reflect on how many times you have tried to do something good after feeling the guilt of sinning? After doing wrong to another person, do we first seek repentance from God or try to right the wrong by our own strength? We may truly believe that salvation is through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ alone but our sinful minds sometimes instinctively cause us to think otherwise. It is only natural for us to react in such ways, which is why we need to constantly remind ourselves of this great truth.

May the guilt of sinning draw us closer to our Saviour who yearns to forgive. May we spend more hours studying His Word, communing with Him in intimate closet prayer and serving Him so that we may hear His sweet voice saying: "Well done, thou good and faithful servant ... enter thou into the joy of thy Lord." [Matthew 25:21]
19 MARCH.part7: Our Lord Jesus Christ drank the cup of wrath so that we will not have to face judgement according to our works. How are we acting in response to His grace?

20 MARCH.part3: VERSE 7 eternal life in heaven, but Paul here is saying the
20 MARCH.part4: To them who by patient continuance in well doing seek for glory and honour and immortality, eternal life.
20 MARCH.part5:
Paul goes on to tell us that those who seek glory, honour and immortality through perseverance in doing good deeds, God will grant eternal life. As we learnt in yesterday's devotion, Paul is not saying we need to do good works to be saved. Rather, Paul is highlighting the importance of godliness and good works in a believer who has been saved by grace through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ. Yes, all Christians who have faith in the Lord will receive eternal life in heaven, but Paul here is saying the desire to patiently persevere in doing good must be a characteristic of every Christian.

There are seasons in life when our good intentions produce bad results. For example, more time could have been put to good use in studying for the upcoming examinations than serving in church; doing what was best for the Lord's sake at work resulted in no increment or bonus for that year; speaking the truth in love to a loved one resulted in a strained and awkward relationship. These "bad experiences" may tempt us to steer away from doing good, to "not care" or do "some bad" every now and then, but that is not what our Lord wants us to do.

Our Lord fulfilled His promise to us by sending His Son to die for our sins, and He too will fulfil this same promise of immortality, honour and eternal life to those who persevere in doing good; despite the adverse results of doing so. Rest in the fact that our Lord sees all, and knows your heart whenever you persevere in doing good for His name's sake.
20 MARCH.part7: Do we choose to persevere in doing good or to do what is convenient?

21 MARCH.part4: But unto them that are contentious, and do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousness, indignation and wrath.
21 MARCH.part5:
We read in the previous verses that there will be a day of wrath and judgement when all will be judged according to God's righteous standards. God will judge everyone for all the sins they have committed. In today's verse, we consider those who are contentious and do not obey the truth. Matthew Henry comments that those who strive against God, are contentious. He explains that "every wilful sin is a quarrel with God, it is striving with our Maker, the most desperate contention".

The root of our contention with God is the love of sin. This is especially so for the unregenerate man, who being shown the truth, strives against it, rejecting it because he loves sin more than anything else. To the Christian, this struggle is a reality because of the fact we are still in our carnal bodies and subject to the trials and temptations of this world. The apostle Paul aptly describes this in Romans 7:22-24. As long as we live in our sin- cursed mortal bodies, we will struggle with sin and the temptation to sin.

How then should we guard ourselves against contention and disobedience? Let us put aside our pride and our love for sin, and put on Jesus Christ; "that ye put off ... the old man, which is corrupt according to the deceitful lusts; ... and that ye put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousness and true holiness" [Ephesians 4:22- 24].
21 MARCH.part7: Only by pride cometh contention: but with the well advised is wisdom. - Proverbs 13:10

22 MARCH.part4: But unto them that are contentious, and do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousness, indignation and wrath
22 MARCH.part5:
As any parent knows, children are most afraid of the displeasure of their father or mother when they misbehave. Good parents who rule over their household well, need only to display their displeasure towards a child's wrongdoing to stop them in their tracks and bring them back to repentance. In Romans 2:8, we see God's response towards those who are contending against Him, who do not obey the truth but obey unrighteousness. Matthew Henry writes, "Those that refuse to be the servants of truth will soon be the slaves of unrighteousness."

To these, God shows His displeasure through His indignation and wrath. "It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God" [Hebrews 10:31]. To the unrepentant sinner, God reserves His displeasure and anger, and on the day of judgement, the sinner will be without excuse, having lived their lives in contention against God and disobedience to His truth. "And fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul: but rather fear Him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell" [Matthew 10:28].

Let us even right now examine our lives to see if we are deserving of God's indignation and wrath. Better still, ask God, who is all merciful and compassionate, to search our hearts and reveal to us areas of our lives where we may have transgressed His holy laws, that we may seek His forgiveness and be cleansed through the blood and righteousness of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.
22 MARCH.part7: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God. - Romans 12:2

23 MARCH.part4: Tribulation and anguish, upon every soul of man that doeth evil, of the Jew first, and also of the Gentile;
23 MARCH.part5:
Yesterday, we saw how God shows His displeasure towards those who are contentious and disobedient. Today's verse continues with the effect of God's indignation and wrath. To every person who does evil, regardless of whether they are Jew or Gentile, there will be tribulation and anguish as a consequence of their sinful deeds. To the unrepentant soul is reserved, on the final judgement day, God's displeasure and wrath, which will be terrible to bear. His soul will be tormented in hell, in eternal tribulation and anguish.

Dear reader, it is imperative that we reach out to our loved ones and friends with the Gospel of the Lord Jesus Christ, to bring them to a saving knowledge of what He had done on the cross for us. Tell them the terrifying end of sinners, how God's terrible punishment is reserved for them on judgment day, and how eternal conscious torment and suffering will be all a sinner experiences in hell for all eternity. Tell them how the Lord Jesus Christ, the sinless Lamb of God, died on the cross, and whosoever believes in Him shall have their sins forgiven and cleansed. They shall stand before God, accepted as His sons and daughters, made righteous through the atoning blood and imputed righteousness of the Lord Jesus Christ.

So let us work while it is still day, because Christ is coming back again to judge all according to their works.
23 MARCH.part7: For the wages of sin is death; but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord. - Romans 6:23

24 MARCH.part4: Tribulation and anguish, upon every soul of man that doeth evil, of the Jew first, and also of the Gentile;
24 MARCH.part5:
In an ironic twist, Paul uses the same phrase that maintained the priority of the Jew as the recipient of the good news of salvation [Romans 1:16] to assert the same priority in judgment. As the word of the promise has gone "first" to the Jew, so does punishment for failure to respond to that word go "first" to the Jew. In contrast with the Jews' tendency to regard their election as a guarantee they would be "first" in salvation and "last" in judgment, Paul insists their priority would be applied equally to both. God will hold those with greater revelation more accountable.

It may be that the Gospel promises have come to a number of us early on in our lives before others. We had the opportunity to hear the Gospel in Christian homes and in Christian circles. We had the freedom to sit under the preaching of the Word. It was indeed such a blessing and privilege to know the Lord Jesus Christ.

However, in Luke 12:35-48, the parable reminds us that "unto whomsoever much is given, of him shall be much required". This is a reminder for us who are privileged and have the advantage of knowing God's will through His revealed Word. Do we simply ignore God's commands which we have often heard and been taught through the years? Do we not heed the call to do His kingdom work but instead occupy ourselves with the cares of the world?
24 MARCH.part7: And that servant, which knew his lord's will, and prepared not himself, neither did according to his will, shall be beaten with many stripes. - Luke 12:47

25 MARCH.part3: VERSE 10 expression in the believer's life. And before the
25 MARCH.part4: But glory, honour, and peace, to every man that worketh good, to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile.
25 MARCH.part5:
We already know "by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in His sight" [Romans 3:20], and thus salvation cannot be bought by good works. Therefore, verse 10 must pertain to Christians who persistently engage in doing good. Christians, and only Christians, because of their union with the Lord Jesus Christ, are able to produce works acceptable to God in the judgment. This is possible as the fruit of faith comes to expression in the believer's life. And before the judgment seat of Christ, everyone will "receive the things done in his body, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad" [2 Corinthians 5:10].

The reward for such is glory, honour, and peace. It is marvellous that not only are we blessed with undeserving salvation, but God has also showered us with His blessing of glory, honour, and peace. The word "peace" should be interpreted in its broadest sense, as indicating salvation full and free, joyful and never-ending participation, with a renewed soul and body, in all the blessings of the new heaven and earth. This, of course, includes sweet fellowship with the Triune God and with all the redeemed.

Although the priority in the disbursement of judgment has the same order of Jews followed by the Gentiles, note that the standard of judgment is the same. God will judge every person on the same basis - by works, not by religious heritage or national identity. God will not deal more generously with the Jew than with the Gentile.
25 MARCH.part7: To Paul, a faith which did not lead to action was a travesty of faith; in fact, it was not faith at all. He would have said that the only way in which you can see people's faith at all is by their actions. Do your actions confirm your faith?

26 MARCH.part4: For there is no respect of persons with God.
26 MARCH.part5:
We live in a world of inequity and inequality. Man must have the respect of persons in the intricate web of human affairs: the presidential train should cause the ordinary express to take the side track; the table of honour should seat the more distinguished guests. And there are human affairs where unfair and preferential treatment is shown in job promotions, favours, judicial rulings based on race, wealth, social status, beauty and not on merit. With regards to salvation, however, God looks with perfect equity on both Jew and Gentile; in other words, God has no favorites.

God offers Heaven equally to the thief on the cross and to the Pharisee. God offers salvation to the high and to the low. God offers salvation to the intellectual and to the ignoramus. And if we stop to analyse it, we can see that it is the only path open to pure justice. Suppose God made salvation contingent on the understanding of theology, then the intelligent would be saved and the ignorant lost. That would not be just. Suppose God made salvation contingent on material possession, then the wealthy would be saved and those born to poverty would be lost. That would not be just. God sees us all as lost sons of Adam.

As image-bearers of the Lord Jesus Christ, we too should emulate this impartiality in our daily lives. James tells us that ministering both to the rich and the poor is fulfilling the royal law of loving "thy neighbour as thyself " [James 2:8]. So, no matter who steps into the church, may we look upon them as lost souls who need to hear the good news of the Gospel. And once they are saved, no matter if they are rich or poor, may we be no respecter of persons but look upon them as children of God.
26 MARCH.part7: Dear God, thank You for being just and no respecter of persons. May You help me to demonstrate the same impartiality in my service and ministry for You. Amen.

27 MARCH.part3: VERSE 12 of God's law will still be judged by the civil law
27 MARCH.part4: For as many as have sinned without law shall also perish without law: and as many as have sinned in the law shall be judged by the law.
27 MARCH.part5:
The apostle Paul addresses two groups of people here - those who have not heard the law ("without law"), and those who are given God's law. For the latter, it seems there is no excuse if they should wilfully violate God's law (having known it), but how about the former group? Can they claim to be blameless on the grounds of ignorance, since God's law was not explicitly declared to them?

The answer is no. Those who are not aware of God's law will still be judged by the civil law of society and more importantly, the law in their conscience. The civil law in society is given by the common grace of God. Every community has, to different extents, an awareness of what is universally right and wrong, which is aligned to God's standard and judgment. Besides that, when man without knowledge of God's law violates what by nature he was designed for or the common interest of his community, he will also be condemned by his conscience, because the moral law has been written in his heart.

Paul is not talking about salvation by works here. Instead, he is highlighting man's depravity. Man, without the grace of God, is condemned. Led by his lust and pride, he will always fall short of God's requirement. A law-abiding citizen might take consolation in not having committed anything society could find fault with, but his conscience will find him to have fallen short, be it from sinful thoughts harboured deep within his heart, or unbecoming words and actions he has been able to conceal from man's eyes.
27 MARCH.part7: For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God. - Romans 3:23

28 MARCH.part4: For as many as have sinned without law shall also perish without law: and as many as have sinned in the law shall be judged by the law.
28 MARCH.part5:
Yesterday we considered those who do not know God's law. Now we examine those who are "in the law". The Jews in Paul's context were well- known for their piety. They deemed themselves the privileged ones who were given God's law, and thus knew God's direction for righteousness. Problem is, they thought they could meet God's standard in their own strength.

It is perhaps not surprising to see some confidently claiming they had kept all the commandments, thus deserving of eternal life [Luke 18:18-21]. We are reminded in the Lord's teaching that this presumptuousness, leading to self-righteousness, is misplaced and results in a worse spiritual condition [Luke 18:10-14]. The truth is no one can meet the standard of God's holy law.

The two groups of people mentioned yesterday and today are similar in some ways. Both sought justification against God's judgment in their own wisdom. Those not knowing God's law excuse themselves on the grounds of ignorance. Those who knew God's law justify themselves by their good works and observance of the law. Both were sadly mistaken. With or without the knowledge of the law, both have sinned, both will be judged, and both condemned.

All must realize they are hopeless without God's mercy and grace, "that they should seek the Lord, if haply they might feel after Him, and find Him, though He be not far from every one of us" [Acts 17:27]. The right understanding of our depravity is the first step to seeking God and being found by Him.
28 MARCH.part7: And they that heard it said, Who then can be saved? And He said, The things which are impossible with men are possible with God. - Luke 18:26-27

29 MARCH.part4: For not the hearers of the law are just before God, but the doers of the law shall be justified.
29 MARCH.part5:
The hearing of God's Word is the first step to believing, for "faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God" [Romans 10:17]. Yet Paul reminds us here it would be of no effect if we just stop at hearing. Many lives have been wasted because their reaction to God's Word was "we will hear thee again of this matter" [Acts 17:32]. Many opportunities were lost because of the lack of follow-through after the seeds of the Gospel were sown, in order that men would cleave to it and believe [Acts 17:34].

The Lord Jesus told a parable in Matthew 13. The Gospel seed sown into hearts of men could fall by the wayside and eaten by fowls; they could fall on the stony places and grow no roots; they could land among thorns and be choked by them. The world has a way of undoing the work of the sower, but the seed falling on prepared soil would bear the fruit of repentance.

Let this be a reminder to those who believe. We often think hearing has to do only with non- believers. But our Lord also painted a picture of the victorious believer: "But he that received seed into the good ground is he that heareth the word, and understandeth it; which also beareth fruit, and bringeth forth, some an hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty" [Matthew 13:23].

Believers should be bearing the fruit of the Spirit, not to earn salvation, but as a result of it. "Even so every good tree bringeth forth good fruit; but a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit" [Matthew 7:17].
29 MARCH.part7: Who hath ears to hear, let him hear. - Matthew 13:9

30 MARCH.part4: For not the hearers of the law are just before God, but the doers of the law shall be justified.
30 MARCH.part5:
"The doers of the law shall be justified." This again looks like a call for salvation by works. But Paul is gradually bringing his readers round to the Gospel; indeed no one is able to fulfil the law's requirement fully - be it through his genuine efforts or his hypocritical application of it.

Some during Paul's time might truly be seeking justification through obedience. We are often cynical about the Pharisees' efforts, but there were those possessed of true zeal. The Lord Jesus once said, "For I say unto you, That except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven" [Matthew 5:20]. We could even say that Paul, before his conversion, was a sincere believer of God. Paul sincerely thought he could be justified by doing everything required of the law, and his persecution of Christians was a misguided understanding of God's truth.

Yet it is also true that there were hypocrites during Paul's time who knowing the demands of God's law, sought only to adhere to it superficially, deceiving both self and others. Upon these the Lord pronounced, "Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye are like unto whited sepulchres, which indeed appear beautiful outward, but are within full of dead men's bones, and of all uncleanness. Even so ye also outwardly appear righteous unto men, but within ye are full of hypocrisy and iniquity" [Matthew 23:27-28].
30 MARCH.part7: Every way of a man is right in his own eyes: but the LORD pondereth the hearts. - Proverbs 21:2

31 MARCH.part4: For not the hearers of the law are just before God, but the doers of the law shall be justified.
31 MARCH.part5:
In the reformed confessions, the purposes of God's law are summarized as three. Firstly, it acts as a curb to keep our sinful nature in check. Believer or not, God's law should stop a sinner in his track and prevent him from sinning further. God's law warns the sinner of the consequences of sinful actions. It is not by chance that the Ten Commandments are phrased in the strongest prohibitive tense in the original language.

Secondly, it serves as a mirror to reflect the sinner's sinfulness against the light of God's perfection and point him toward the Saviour. "For if any be a hearer of the Word, and not a doer, he is like unto a man beholding his natural face in a glass: For he beholdeth himself, and goeth his way, and straightway forgetteth what manner of man he was. But whoso looketh into the perfect law of liberty, and continueth therein, he being not a forgetful hearer, but a doer of the work, this man shall be blessed in his deed" [James 1:23-25].

Thirdly, for believers, it is a guide to help them live a regenerated and God-pleasing life. Justified by the finished work of the Lord Jesus Christ, we do not rely on our own good works to be saved. Yet God's law gives us direction in our sanctification. It tells us what God loves and hates. With each passing day, we can therefore seek to align our will with God's, "confident of this very thing, that He which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ" [Philippians 1:6].
31 MARCH.part7: But be ye doers of the Word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves. - James 1:22
